DOC.brief_summary: Selective Internal Radiation Therapy is superior to Transarterial Chemoembolisation for the treatment of intermediate stage hepatocellular carcinoma.
DOC.brief_title: Selective Internal Radiation Therapy (SIRT) Versus Transarterial Chemoembolisation (TACE) for the Treatment of Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC).
DOC.criteria: ≥18 years HCC, proven by histology or according to EASL criteria Intermediate stage HCC (stage B according to BCLC) At least one measurable lesion in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) Tumor load ≤ 50% preserved liver function (Child Pugh A and B) Patients feasible for curative treatment (e.g. resection or local ablation) Previous TACE or SIRT Chemotherapy during the last 4 weeks Child Pugh stage C BCLC stage D ECOG Performance Status >0 Tumor involvement >50% of the liver Extrahepatic tumor Serum Bilirubin >2.0 mg/dl; Serum Albumin 2.8 g/dl, Serum Creatinine >2 mg/dl; Leukocytes <3000/ml; Thrombocytes <50000/ml Clinically apparent ascites (ascites only in CT/MRI is no exclusion criteria) Esophageal bleeding during the last 3 months Hepatic encephalopathy Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) Infiltration or occlusion of the portal vein Hepatofugal blood flow in the portal vein Hepatopulmonary shunt ≥ 20% in the macroaggregated albumin scan Contraindications against angiography Gravidity
